nodes.text: the public has never been allowed in jury rooms and with good reason
Allowing cameras in the jury room would also harm the deliberative process.
If a Judge's action would harm the deliberative process of the jury that is a reason not to carry out the action.

Jurors especially less educated and articulate ones may be wary of speaking out if they know they are being judged by an audience at home. They may be more reluctant to question the credibility of a witness or to take an unpopular stand like holding out for an acquittal or against the death penalty.
If Jurors may be more reluctant to speak out in front of cameras then if cameras are allowed into the jury room the deliberative process will be harmed
Televising jury deliberations will skew the composition of juries by removing people who do not want to reach a verdict - and in this case possibly impose the death penalty - on a public stage
If a Judge's action would skew the composition of the jury that is a reason not to carry out the action.
Telivising Mr. Harrison's case has skewed the jury by removing people who do not want to reach a verdict on a public stage.

If televising Mr. Harrison's case has skewed the jury by removing people who do not want to reach a verdict on a public stage it is likely that televising jury deliberations in the future will have the same effect
If one removes all those who do not want to reach a verdict on a public stage from a jury and these people may be precisely the ones best suited to serve its composition will thus be skewed.
So far at least 14 out of 110 prospective jurors in Mr. Harrison's case have been excused for reasons related to the presence of cameras.
These jurors may be precisely the ones best suited to serve
Those who fulfill the role of jurors are entitled to privacy in doing so
If those who fulfill a duty are entitled to privacy in doing so there is a reason not to take this privacy away from them

Jurors are not government officials and do not perform a representational function. Being a juror is more akin to voting a civic duty that occurs in private. Like voters in an exit poll jurors ought to be free to speak afterward about their deliberations but they are not obligated to.
If a civic duty is not representational those who fulfill it are entitled to privacy in doing so.
